org.microbean.kubernetes.controller

Class EventQueueCollection<T extends HasMetadata>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.microbean.kubernetes.controller.EventQueueCollection<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - a type of Kubernetes resource
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable, Iterable<EventQueue<T>>, EventCache<T>

    @ThreadSafe
public class EventQueueCollection<T extends HasMetadata>
extends Object
implements EventCache<T>, Iterable<EventQueue<T>>, AutoCloseable
    An EventCache that temporarily stores Events in EventQueues, one per named Kubernetes resource, and provides a means for processing those queues.

    Thread Safety

    This class is safe for concurrent use by multiple Threads. Some operations, like the usage of the iterator() method, require that callers synchronize on the EventQueue directly. This class' internals synchronize on this when locking is needed.

    Author:
    Laird Nelson
    See Also:
    add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata), replace(Collection, Object), synchronize(), start(Consumer), EventQueue

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  EventQueueCollection.TransientException
      A RuntimeException indicating that a Consumer started by an EventQueueCollection has encountered an error that might not happen if the consumption operation is retried.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      EventQueueCollection()
      Creates a new EventQueueCollection with an initial capacity of 16 and a load factor of 0.75 that is not interested in tracking Kubernetes resource deletions.
      EventQueueCollection(Map<?,? extends T> knownObjects)
      Creates a new EventQueueCollection with an initial capacity of 16 and a load factor of 0.75.
      EventQueueCollection(Map<?,? extends T> knownObjects, int initialCapacity, float loadFactor)
      Creates a new EventQueueCollection.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description

      Adds a new Event constructed out of the parameters supplied to this method to this EventQueueCollection and returns the Event that was added.
      void close()
      Semantically closes this EventQueueCollection by detaching any Consumer previously attached via the start(Consumer) method.
      protected Event<T> createEvent(Object source, Event.Type eventType, T resource)
      Creates an Event using the supplied raw materials and returns it.
      protected EventQueue<T> createEventQueue(Object key)
      Creates a new EventQueue suitable for holding Events matching the supplied key.
      void forEach(Consumer<? super EventQueue<T>> action)
      Invokes the Consumer.accept(Object) method for each EventQueue stored by this EventQueueCollection.
      protected Object getKey(T resource)
      Returns an Object which will be used as the key that will uniquely identify the supplied resource to this EventQueueCollection.
      boolean isSynchronized()
      Returns true if this EventQueueCollection has been populated via a call to add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata) at some point, and if there are no EventQueues remaining to be removed.
      Iterator<EventQueue<T>> iterator()
      Returns an Iterator of EventQueue instances that are created and managed by this EventQueueCollection as a result of the add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata), replace(Collection, Object) and synchronize() methods.
      void replace(Collection<? extends T> incomingResources, Object resourceVersion)
      At a high level, fully replaces the internal state of this EventQueueCollection to reflect only the Kubernetes resources contained in the supplied Collection, notionally firing Events of type Event.Type.SYNCHRONIZATION and Event.Type.DELETION as appropriate.
      Spliterator<EventQueue<T>> spliterator()
      Returns a Spliterator of EventQueue instances that are created and managed by this EventQueueCollection as a result of the add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata), replace(Collection, Object) and synchronize() methods.
      void start(Consumer<? super EventQueue<? extends T>> siphon)
      Starts a new daemon Thread that, until close() is called, removes EventQueues from this EventQueueCollection and supplies them to the supplied Consumer.
      void synchronize()
      Synchronizes on the knownObjects object supplied at construction time, if there is one, and, for every Kubernetes resource found within at the time of this call, adds an Event with an Event.Type of Event.Type.SYNCHRONIZATION for it.

    • Constructor Detail

      • EventQueueCollection

        public EventQueueCollection()
        Creates a new EventQueueCollection with an initial capacity of 16 and a load factor of 0.75 that is not interested in tracking Kubernetes resource deletions.
        See Also:
        EventQueueCollection(Map, int, float)

      • EventQueueCollection

        public EventQueueCollection(Map<?,? extends T> knownObjects)
        Creates a new EventQueueCollection with an initial capacity of 16 and a load factor of 0.75.
        Parameters:
        knownObjects - a Map containing the last known state of Kubernetes resources this EventQueueCollection is caching events for; may be null if this EventQueueCollection is not interested in tracking deletions of objects; if non-null will be synchronized on by this class during retrieval and traversal operations
        See Also:
        EventQueueCollection(Map, int, float)

      • EventQueueCollection

        public EventQueueCollection(Map<?,? extends T> knownObjects,
                            int initialCapacity,
                            float loadFactor)
        Creates a new EventQueueCollection.
        Parameters:
        knownObjects - a Map containing the last known state of Kubernetes resources this EventQueueCollection is caching events for; may be null if this EventQueueCollection is not interested in tracking deletions of objects; if non-null will be synchronized on by this class during retrieval and traversal operations
        initialCapacity - the initial capacity of the internal data structure used to house this EventQueueCollection's EventQueues; must be an integer greater than 0
        loadFactor - the load factor of the internal data structure used to house this EventQueueCollection's EventQueues; must be a positive number between 0 and 1

    • Method Detail

      • iterator

        public final Iterator<EventQueue<T>> iterator()
        Returns an Iterator of EventQueue instances that are created and managed by this EventQueueCollection as a result of the add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata), replace(Collection, Object) and synchronize() methods.

        To call this method and then use this Iterator you must synchronize on this EventQueueCollection.

        This method never returns null.

        The returned Iterator's Iterator.remove() method throws an UnsupportedOperationException.

        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<EventQueue<T extends HasMetadata>>
        Returns:
        a non-null Iterator of EventQueues

      • spliterator

        public final Spliterator<EventQueue<T>> spliterator()
        Returns a Spliterator of EventQueue instances that are created and managed by this EventQueueCollection as a result of the add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata), replace(Collection, Object) and synchronize() methods.

        To call this method and then use this Spliterator you must synchronize on this EventQueueCollection.

        This method never returns null.

        Specified by:
        spliterator in interface Iterable<EventQueue<T extends HasMetadata>>
        Returns:
        a non-null Spliterator of EventQueues
        See Also:
        Collection.spliterator()

      • forEach

        public final void forEach(Consumer<? super EventQueue<T>> action)
        Invokes the Consumer.accept(Object) method for each EventQueue stored by this EventQueueCollection.
        Specified by:
        forEach in interface Iterable<EventQueue<T extends HasMetadata>>
        Parameters:
        a - Consumer of EventQueues; may be null in which case no action will be taken
        See Also:
        Iterable.forEach(Consumer)

      • isSynchronized

        public final boolean isSynchronized()
        Returns true if this EventQueueCollection has been populated via a call to add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata) at some point, and if there are no EventQueues remaining to be removed.
        See Also:
        replace(Collection, Object), add(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata), synchronize()

      • synchronize

        public final void synchronize()
        Synchronizes on the knownObjects object supplied at construction time, if there is one, and, for every Kubernetes resource found within at the time of this call, adds an Event with an Event.Type of Event.Type.SYNCHRONIZATION for it.
        Specified by:
        synchronize in interface EventCache<T extends HasMetadata>

      • replace

        public final void replace(Collection<? extends T> incomingResources,
                          Object resourceVersion)
        At a high level, fully replaces the internal state of this EventQueueCollection to reflect only the Kubernetes resources contained in the supplied Collection, notionally firing Events of type Event.Type.SYNCHRONIZATION and Event.Type.DELETION as appropriate.

        EventQueues managed by this EventQueueCollection that have not yet been processed are not removed by this operation.

        This method synchronizes on the supplied incomingResources Collection while iterating over it.

        Specified by:
        replace in interface EventCache<T extends HasMetadata>
        Parameters:
        incomingResources - the Collection of Kubernetes resources with which to replace this EventQueueCollection's internal state; may be null or empty, which will be taken as an indication that this EventQueueCollection should effectively be emptied
        resourceVersion - the version of the Kubernetes list resource that contained the incoming resources; currently ignored; may be null
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the createEvent(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata) method returns null for any reason
        See Also:
        Event.Type.SYNCHRONIZATION, createEvent(Object, Event.Type, HasMetadata)

      • getKey

        protected Object getKey(T resource)
        Returns an Object which will be used as the key that will uniquely identify the supplied resource to this EventQueueCollection.

        This method may return null, but only if resource is null or is constructed in such a way that its HasMetadata.getMetadata() method returns null.

        Overrides of this method may return null, but only if resource is null.

        The default implementation of this method returns the return value of the HasMetadatas.getKey(HasMetadata) method.

        Parameters:
        resource - a HasMetadata for which a key should be returned; may be null in which case null may be returned
        Returns:
        a non-null key for the supplied resource; or null if resource is null
        See Also:
        HasMetadatas.getKey(HasMetadata)

      • createEventQueue

        protected EventQueue<T> createEventQueue(Object key)
        Creates a new EventQueue suitable for holding Events matching the supplied key.

        This method never returns null.

        Overrides of this method must not return null.

        Parameters:
        the - key for the new EventQueue; must not be null
        Returns:
        the new EventQueue; never null
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if key is null
        See Also:
        EventQueue.EventQueue(Object)

      • start

        @NonBlocking
public final void start(Consumer<? super EventQueue<? extends T>> siphon)
        Starts a new daemon Thread that, until close() is called, removes EventQueues from this EventQueueCollection and supplies them to the supplied Consumer.

        Invoking this method does not block the calling Thread.

        Parameters:
        siphon - the Consumer that will process each EventQueue as it becomes ready; must not be null
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if siphon is null

      • close

        public final void close()
        Semantically closes this EventQueueCollection by detaching any Consumer previously attached via the start(Consumer) method. Additions, replacements and synchronizations are still possible, but there won't be anything consuming any events generated by or supplied to these operations.

        A closed EventQueueCollection may be started again.

        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable
        See Also:
        start(Consumer)

      • createEvent

        protected Event<T> createEvent(Object source,
                               Event.Type eventType,
                               T resource)
        Creates an Event using the supplied raw materials and returns it.

        This method never returns null.

        Implementations of this method must not return null.

        Implementations of this method must return a new Event with every invocation.

        Parameters:
        source - the source of the Event that will be created; must not be null
        eventType - the type of Event that will be created; must not be null
        resource - the resource of the Event that will be created; must not be null

      • add

        public final Event<T> add(Object source,
                          Event.Type eventType,
                          T resource)
        Adds a new Event constructed out of the parameters supplied to this method to this EventQueueCollection and returns the Event that was added.

        This method may return null.

        This implementation creates an EventQueue if necessary for the Event that will be added, and then adds the new Event to the queue.

        Specified by:
        add in interface EventCache<T extends HasMetadata>
        Parameters:
        source - the source of the Event that will be created and added; must not be null
        eventType - the type of Event that will be created and added; must not be null
        resource - the resource of the Event that will be created and added; must not be null
        Returns:
        the Event that was created and added, or null if no Event was actually added as a result of this method's invocation
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if any of the parameters is null
        See Also:
        Event
